Same for all home appliances.  All gas or wood burning stoves, fireplaces, grill, etc are outlawed.  No more flowers, grass or any other ornamental plants of any kind. Kloko,
The term 'climate denier' is used by people that have no comprehension of the magnitude of the variability of climate and it's causes or just how uncertain science is about it.
Tota belief in something without question is a religion, no more.
As Richard Feynmann said "Science is the belief in the ignorance of experts"
author: I A Reid

text:
¬†@I A Reid¬† Yes, that what climate deniers say.
Man made warming is a fact like gravity is a fact.
author: Kloko Loko

text:
Kloko, 

there is warming but it is not man made. There is no evidence and much discussion goes on about the amount of influence the very small amount of CO2 man emits (5% of total emissions) actually has.
To say, as some do, that all the warming is due to man is simply implausible. Just think about it as we have had periods in the past warmer than this when there as no influence from man.
If you believe that man is the only cause then that's up to you, but I suggest that you look further.
What is happening that governments are spending or planning to spend trillions of dollars, pounds, Euros etc on a futile mission to 'control the climate' which cannot work.
That money could be far better spent to improve the lifes of millions of people but instead it will be wasted.

text: We are not climate deniers thats the group we are put into because we dont support all your claims. There is no crisis. There is a warming occuring but very little. Common thinking among scientists is change is a gradual process over a period of time. The data is out there that prooves otherwise. It is in the ice cores of an iceland glacier scientists have been coring for 5 years starting I believe in the mid 90s. Samples were takin at the deepest point approx. 2 miles thick. They have been analyzing the samples since. In these samples you will find the ebbs and flows of global climate. Interesting research. There is even more data in other areas which match up to mentioned data. Its all out there but few are examining it or maybe they dont want to go against traditional thinking.

Debemos tomar conciencia de la destrucci√≥n que estamos generando, no digo que de un dia para otro cambiemos todo. Pero hay cientos de cosas que dia a dia podemos cambiar, cosas simples, estamos acostumbrados a dejar las luces de las casas encendidas cuando nos vamos, a dejar que el agua del grifo corra cuando nos lavamos los dientes o la dejamos corriendo por minutos cuando lavamos los platos. Podemos apostar por los autos electricos, reciclar no cuesta nada, separar nuestros reciduos, no botar basura en las calles, poemos dejar de usar el aire acondicionado todo el dia, aveces nisiquiera es necesario y aun asi lo prendemos porque nos acostumbramos a esa comodidad, podemos exigir que todo el transporte publico sea el√©ctrico, exigir a nuestros gobiernos que les ponga un alto a las empresas que tiran toneladas de desperdicios a nuetros rios, podemos come mejor(no hablo de ser vegano) pero debemos parar de desperdiciar comida, esto lo hacemos porque nos sobra. text: When I was in Primary school in Australia in the late 70s, early 80s each of us was given a small tree to plant either at home or on the school grounds. Each child was responsible for planting and nurturing it until it showed growth. There are over 400 million primary aged school children in the world.  Wouldn't it be great if our Governments around the world started a similar program to educate our young people and start the process of rebuilding our trees.  A small investment for a large return. Every seed planted would serve two purposes. The life of a new tree and the seed of knowledge in our youth to help make more environmentally conscious people in the world.

text:
Very nice, and to foster some positive discussion I would like to add that when it comes to what "you" can do to help, this Protect-Restore-Fund solution could be an amazing trigger for deeper self reflective thoughts. 

Protect, restore and fund are actions and as such they imply some underlying motive. The way we generally act today (i.e. buying products off the shelves of stores without knowing how they got there or even what they are, and keep consuming without worrying about what we're actually doing when we consume) has also got some underlying motivations, namely we are chasing wellbeing/reward/satisfaction/happiness. It is a self-centered motive. Protect, restore, and fund are actions that stem from a caring desire, they are fostering and supportive actions which come from a much more care-oriented standpoint, or more parenting standpoint. 

I guess I'm not gonna go too far in saying that it is us in the first place who have generated this system that keeps us in a vicious cycle of evermore childish behaviours. This is really a call to our adulthood, which means waking up to our personal responsibility and personal power. We need to become organized and learn to connect and collaborate with each other. This is a bottom-up movement.


Please let's open the discussion and think about this in more practical terms, I have many more ideas to contribute with.

You are suggesting a DENY OF THE FREE MARKT. You are denying the FREEDOM OF EACH HUMAN. You are trying to START A COLLAPSE OF THE WORLD ORDER. text:
There are sooooo many things wrong in this video that it's hard to debunk it with a single comment and no more than 10 lines. I'll thus cite only a couple of reasons why the statements made on the video above are absurdly damn wrong:
1. Trees spend 12 hours converting CO2 in O2 and the next 12 hours converting O2 in CO2. Therefore, trees are not the "lungs of the planet", they are not "oxygen makers".
2. Our atmosphere currently has 400ppm of CO2. Plants need at least 150ppm of CO2 in the atmosphere in order to live. If we reduce the CO2 concentration to a level below 150ppm, our plants will first starve, then stop growing, then die. Ironically, this will destroy the very same environment that these "environmentalists" state that they're trying to save. Also ironically, such extinction of plants will also lead to our own extinction.

Environmentalists must stop associating conservation with climate and CO2 reduction. Humans can not regulate the global climate by controlling the CO2 emissions. We do have to preserve Nature and its biodiversity, but not because of global warming and not by reducing CO2 emissions, this is NONSENSE.

text: What they failed to mention was that we can harvest mature trees, turn the logs into building products and store the carbon in long-lived buildings that can last for centuries.  If we leave the trees to simply grow and then die, the rotting wood uses oxygen from the air and creates carbon dioxide.  Rotting wood, or anything else, is the same oxidation reduction reaction as fire, but it only happens more slowly.  The wise use of some of our forest resources will, in fact, further improve our planet.

text: Once Again, Climate Warriors Rescued from Their Ship Trapped in Polar Ice. A similar incident five years ago involved passengers on a ‚Äòscientific expedition‚Äô to document ice melt and, it too, had to be rescued. text:
¬†@N V Clarke¬† it's premature to say climate change is not natural. You might confuse the human contribution to the climate change with the natural phenomenon of climate change itself. No scientist can deny that. 
It is well known that global warming was in fact happening before the Industrial Revolution but it was relatively slow, as part of Earth's cycles. Since the WW2 the phenomenon escalated dramatically and that's why it's so alarming for such a short period of time. But such scenarios were common in the history of Earth.
Everything about this drama that is happening today happens only for one reason. Humans realized they cannot have the total control over nature.

text: Mister Schmitler yeah, you‚Äôre right. And I‚Äôm glad there are people who are pretty informed on these things. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a lot more I could learn. But that is a fact I‚Äôve been exposed to. What do you think about the way animal agriculture contributes to global warming? That‚Äôs a pretty interesting facet of this topic, imo (of course all food production will contribute to our problems by some amount, but I‚Äôve heard that animal agriculture is measurably and significantly worse for the planet than strictly plant-based agriculture)
author: 90MysteriumFascinans

text: ¬†@90MysteriumFascinans¬† If animal farming is bad (which it has to be if one is an eco activist) then what about all the vast herds of large herbivors that roamed (or used to) the planet? There were 60 million Bison in the US to take one example.
author: Stephen Skinner

text: Stephen Skinner as far as I know, it‚Äôs not their mere existence that‚Äôs damaging. It‚Äôs the runoff into water, the lack of natural ecosystem balance that would be able to process the output from the animals. And also the clear cutting and destruction of whole ecosystems. But tbh I don‚Äôt know the details offhand beyond that. It‚Äôs definitely an interesting thought that we could collectively improve our climate catastrophe by no longer purchasing animal products (and reducing the scale of the industry).
author: 90MysteriumFascinans

text:
¬†@90MysteriumFascinans¬† And what of the clear cutting to grow bio fuels such as palm oil? The EU imports 6 million tons for bio fuel. The Brazilians have been clear cutting for decades and in 1975 90% of their vehicles ran on sugar produced ethanol (it's now 75%). While Brazil does clear cut for cattle as well as crops, clear cutting elsewhere is mostly done for wood and crops and not cattle. Yes, I understand about the runoff from farms and like all man made problems they are fixable. 
There isn't a climate catastrophe. This has been asserted repeatedly but there isn't. Please see Hans Rosling‚Äôs book 'Factfulness' Chapter 10 'The Urgency Instinct'. Hans Rosling tells how Al Gore said "We need to create fear!" In other words, exaggerate, or lie. 
There are a minimum of 6 climate zones on earth (not one) and they are all still there, including the sub climates. The numbers of people dying from natural events keeps on diminishing with the biggest killers in recent years being earthquakes and tsunamis. However, 7,000 years ago the earth was hotter than now and was hotter still during the Eemian when CO2 was about 300ppm, less than now. The latest data from Mauna Lao shows CO2 continuing to increase in spite of the huge drop in human produced CO2. As it is asserted that it is humans driving the increase in CO2 why is there no sign of this in the data?
author: Stephen Skinner

text:
Yeah, there are other (and bigger) concerns than just animal agriculture. It just seems like one of the easier ways for consumers to make any sort of impact. But yes, mostly the issue is industrial activity, so the consumer can‚Äôt solely resolve the crisis, and there are all sorts of things we can rightfully point to in terms of where we must change what humans are doing. 

I‚Äôm inclined to disagree about your stance on the climate catastrophe... The urgency comes from scientific measurements and models, so is not manufactured. But thanks for the book recommendation. I‚Äôd be interested in fact-checking my own understanding/assumptions, as well as those at the core of a book that supports your statements. 
With the record-setting wildfires, and increased number of heat deaths, and also people already displaced or vulnerable to displacement from sea level rise, as well as crop failure, drought... I‚Äôd definitely disagree with the concept that there is or will continue to be a small # of deaths from the increased temperatures. But, like most people, I could benefit from educating myself better, to really be able to assert any of this credibly/factually.

Also, could you explain the comment about the huge drop in human produced co2? Do you mean with reduced activity during the pandemic, or..? I can‚Äôt seem to find that reflected (at all) in the longer-term data I‚Äôm looking at.

text: ¬†@John Peric¬† I disagree, but even if they aren't, does that discredit what they're saying?
author: 91dpo

text: ¬†@John Peric¬† I know what a hypocrite is. Do you realise that Greta doesn't fly? That she travelled by boat to America? We're all hypocrites, people continue to smoke despite knowing the health risks. All I can do is listen to the science.
author: 91dpo

text:
¬†@91dpo¬† Actually, the boat was a publicity stunt, and advertisement to say the least. When she went back to Europe, she went back on a Jet.


Five of the people from her team didn't even come by boat, they flew by plane from Europe to the U.S. to retrieve the boat.


Greta alone would've produced nearly 1 ton of CO2 during that single publicity stunt.


Also, why are you bringing up smoking, and your point makes no sense. People who smoke despite knowing the health risk aren't hypocrites, that's called caring more about your enjoyment than your health. It would be hyprocritical to know smoking is unhealthy and preach others shouldn't do it, while being a smoker yourself.
author: John Peric

text: ¬†@John Peric¬† I guess I had doctors in mind. There are plenty of doctors who are overweight/smoke etc and advise others not to. I think we're going around in circles here anyway, so I'm happy to agree to disagree. I personally don't consider Greta a hypocrite. Even if I did, I would still consider climate change a threat and a problem we all need to address more aggressively than we currently are. Would you agree with me on that?
author: 91dpo

text: ¬†@91dpo¬† No, I agree we should mitigate our effects on the climate, because less climate change is better than more climate change regardless of how little it effects us. However, I do believe we need to cut our Co2 emissions down to near zero as soon as economically possible, because what is an enormous threat to humanity and life on Earth, is ocean acidification, which is a threat to the food supply of 50% of the world (as much as 80% by 2040), and roughly 50% of the species on Earth.
author: John Peric

text: ¬†@John Peric¬† glad we can agree on that! One thing I'm interested in with the ocean is the opportunity to plant seaweed forests - for food, habitat and carbon sequestration.
author: 91dpo

The problem is not the growing population but western overconsumption and industries, in which I include Chinese factories since that's where so many Western corporations make their stuff. "Overpopulation" is not a thing, that fallacy has been debunked many times over. No scientist or economist still believes that's what the problem is. Population control is not the solution. text:
what happens to leaves, flowers, bark, insects, fungi and wood when they die? 
they are carbohydrates: they are consumed by other insects, bacteria and fungi - these
breathe out carbon dioxide and water vapor - just like you, try it now, breathe on your screen
the net effect of a juvenile forest is a slight decrease in carbon dioxide; an ancient forest gives it all back
the only exception is if the nutrients are removed from the process: the most common is sinking in deep ocean
oxygen we breathe today comes from blue-green algae that died (and sank into deep water) millions of years ago
author: Brett B

text: ¬†@madeinlukas¬† No, trees do produce oxygen, as do all plants, with every exhalation too. Phytoplankton you're talking about are ocean plants, but how we treat and use the oceans is causing their numbers to dwindle. The answer is micro-algae: the fastest growing plant known, so best both at creating oxygen and eating/sequestering carbon. If this were to be done on scale in the desert regions, like California, that would be a great help, along with ending oil and stopping clearcut logging. Switching to selection logging is spacing in forest management increases root space for each tree to grow freely, making forest stronger & healthier. This is a known fire mitigation technique too

text:
My family are forest and swamp owners in Finland. Currently we aren't taxed for ownership. We are able to only cut trees for our own usage to heat two houses during the winters and enjoy forest and swamp resources, such as berries.  If we were taxed annually for ownership of land, we would have to cut trees for profit to pay for the taxes. Currently we don't make any monetary profit, so there's nothing to pay from. A lot of forests in Finland are like this - they are like bank accounts, that's value grows very slowly. 

But naturally, trees only have monetary value when they are sold to the industries, such as paper industry. 

The biggest wood buyer, half-national-owned paper company Stora Enso, practises shady business in Amazonia for faster-growing trees and shiny paper. So I'd rather not support it and the like.
 
One option currently is to sell fire wood to towns people with fireplaces, who don't have their own forests.  But I think it would be more productive if we moved away from burning wood for energy in our homes. 

Some wood industries that I can get behind are building from wood and making recyclable and bio-degradable packaging to replace plastic. Wood constuctions last, when kept well, practically forever. Recyclable materials are used over and over without being burned and bio-degradable materials return the carbon to the ground.

But if you want the trees to catch carbon, taxing ownership is a double-edged sword, because there is no way of controlling where that wood is sold.

text: A runaway greenhouse effect is measured by water vapour content that has a cooling function removing latent heat and creating low pressure cool fronts, clouds, and rain for a healthy biosphere. Topographic forests increase the greenhouse effect attracting more water vapour, local low pressure, clouds, and rain. Fossil fuels are vast resources being produced all the time given by the Fischer and Tropsch equations, deeper reserves replenish shallow reserves sometimes at the rate of extraction. While spills are devastating they are allot less and studies show that the over 7,500 oil and gas platforms around the world have dramatically increased the world's fisheries right up to the Whales providing artificial reefs and exclusion zones from trawlers. Electric vehicles rely on hard to get rare earths with radioactive waste. Over half of the world's Soy and Palm Oil grown is for biofuels competing with pre-existing agriculture opening up new land causing mass deforestation.

We are hurting, she and I.

ravaged by countless thoughtless men
for so, so many years.

her scars do not detract, for me,
her loveliness, her splendour
yet how can I not weep for her, 

knowing her afflictions.


by CS 2019

text: True but there are so many factors to mention here that it is better for Greta to talk about the simple high-level picture, not get bogged down in detail. Detail is for the rest of us to sort out. The biggest problem is that the problem is not being taking seriously, which means that fossil fuels are getting literally trillions in subsidies, while forests and other ecosystems are being wiped out. Fix that, and you've also fixed most agriculture (animal and otherwise).
author: Thomas Britz

text: ¬†@Thomas Britz¬† The reason I mentioned it is because "animal agriculture" is not just a detail, it's the leading cause of climate change when you factor in the following - transportation of the animals, the enormous amount of water/food needed, plus deforestation and enormous amount of land required, not to mention the waste/methane produced. Also, animal agriculture is heavily subsidized. As such it should be noted in her conversations.
author: Charles S.

text: ¬†@Charles S.¬† she mentions it in other tweets, etc.
author: Rachel Lively MacKnight

text: ¬†@Charles S.¬† I agree that it is a massive factor, and Greta herself often mentions animal agriculture and that we should go (mostly) vegan. But massive as this is, it is still not the primary message, if we are to simplify matters to these present and clear sound bites. Animal agriculture contributes to the primary problem but is not itself the primary problem: that is the massive emissions of greenhouse gases. Greta addresses secondary issues, like the causes, elsewhere.

text:
I was with you reading your article on The Guardian which wouldn't allow me to comment, until the Fossil Fuel thing.  While it would be sensible to use less or no Fossil Fuel, the narrative is generally that all combustion engines entirely should be banned, which is not at all about climate change and entirely about shifting wealth and economics. 


If we pay attention to how the climate cycle works, how we're using land and what we're getting out of it, there's a lot of land that could be used to grow fuel crops, this cycles carbon more responsibly. In terms of economics it would also allow for domestic fuel production creating domestic jobs and bolstering national economic strength. 


The idea that all combustion engines and high density fuels should simply be replaced with batteries is an unsustainable, ill thought out plan that didn't come about through science and was instead created by climate fear mongering. Imagine a world where only people living in developed cities are able to drive as most rural locations don't and won't have infrastructure capable of supporting electric cars, not to mention many people can't even park near their own homes. 


Imagine a world where only the wealthy city dwellers are able to work jobs away from home and the people who live the furthest away from anything will just what.. dwindle and die out? 


Sounds like a horrible world.


Now imagine a world where the rural residents grow food and fuel for the whole country, while city folk have their electric cars and their public transport and rural folk have their long range high density combustion fuels so they can travel where they need to go to make their business happen. Making better use of our population and our land.


That's a world I'd rather live in.

text:
Sigh... Trees don't work as amazingly as they keep saying. They take years to become effective carbon capturers and each tree alone only takes in a small amount of carbon per year. You need to plant TRILLIONS of trees covering an area larger than Africa in order to just mitigate the co2 we have released, but the natural positive feedback loops in play right now are going to keep the Earth heating up regardless of human activity. We are in a runaway scenario as we speck. So yes, sure we need to act, we need to change every aspect of our lives! but don't count on trees helping you at all it's just not feasible to plant the amount of trees we need to have any meaningful effect. 

We needed to leave the Amazon alone but you can count that as being a loss now too. Just keep hammering nails into your own coffin and forget about it all, seems to be working well so far right? lol

text: ¬†@lsamoa¬† 5G would help people organize and strategize climate restoration efforts more effectively. However, idk why trees need to be chopped down in the process. Source?
author: gerannamoe

text: ¬†@gerannamoe¬† Source is my municipality itself who's finally officially admitted as to why they were cutting down all those trees. Other municipalities elsewhere are doing the same. We don't need 5G to organise our efforts and really shouldn't use it for that. When coordinating or organising groups of people, you need to use the lowest common tech available not the highest one, otherwise you leave people out. And there's no climate-related application for 5G, it's more about implementing the internet of things and speeding up transmission times, rather than about connecting people or serving as a scientific support tool. Also, in many countries 5G interfers with the bandwidth used for emergency first response in case of natural disasters, so it's really not helpful at all for dealing with climate change and its effects. I'm not even going to get into the issue of tech rebound effect, aka Jevons paradox. 5G is not and never will be a green tech.

text: ¬†@James2 N100¬† Please understand that it is NOT the chemical properties of CO2 that are the problem but, the physical property that the CO2 molecule vibrates (heats) in the infrared spectrum. Commercial greenhouses often inject CO2 to speed plant growth but, they also use fans, water coolers, and open window ventilation to control heating.  :-)
author: Brooks Anderson

text:
¬†@James2 N100¬† "Google:"  How could global warming accelerate if CO2 is logarithmic?  Its a Skeptical Science    artical with graphs relating atmospheric CO2 content and temperature . . As a geologist, I use measured effects as opposed to models. As you probably know, deep ice cores at the French Dome C and Russian Vostok Antarctic stations span an 800,000 year  time period. They cover eight glacial advance/retreat cycles of about 100,000 years each. Those advance/retreat cycles have been linked to the Milankovitch cycles of Earth orbital excentricity, precession, and axial tilt. During that time, average ice "air" bubble CO2 content ranged from about 180ppm during glacial advances and 280ppm during glacial retreats. At no time did the CO2 content  of the "air" bubbles exceed 300ppm. The current CO2 content of those bubbles exceeds 414ppm+ and is both rising and accelerating.  
                     Meanwhile,  according to Peter Wadhams,  2017, A Farewell to Ice; a Report from the Arctic, p. 177, who has made some 50 expeditions to the Arctic to measure sea ice aerial extent and thickness, mainly in nuclear submarines,  September Arctic sea ice VOLUME has dropped from about 16 X 10(3rd) Km3 in 1976 to about  5 X 10(3rd) km3 in 2017. 
                    It is worth noting that Pres. Putin is expanding Russia¬¥s nuclear-powered icebreaker fleet and reopening old Soviet naval bases along the Siberian coast.  (The USA has NO nuclear-powered icebreakers.) An open Arctic sea lane will give Russia access to both Siberian petroleum and mineral resources as well as quicker access to the North Pacific for Russia's navy. I rather doubt that Pres. Putin is a fool.       old geologist

text: Greta is an inspiration. No technologies exist that could refreeze the arctic sea ice on the scale necessary to save us. There is no saving us . Consider Aerosol masking effect / global dimming.  Sad but true. Time to stop repeating that old platitude.  Nothing that humans can do will stop the sea ice and glaciers from melting and the seas rising. Last summer the arctic suffered an almost blue water event. Fresh water is pouring into the seas right now, and perma frost is melting at a rapid rate all over the world. The release of methane that comes with permafrost and sea bed melting will accelerate warming. Located within zones that will be severely damaged by seas rising are man's greatest folly, the nuclear power plant. Fuchushima had multiple meltdowns doing its job to help heat the planet with cores burning hotter than the sun, releasing man made radiation in volumes that dwarf the 2500 nuclear bomb test of the 1940s,50s,60s  combined. We were exposed then and now. There are many things that could possibly happen to bring man to extinction. The fact is glacial and sea ice are rapidly melting right now. Humans are sick in ways never known before our biosphere was irreparably irradiated with man's folly. We are living in uncertain times for sure. There are things to be done now to alleviate suffering in the near future. Move away from the rising sea before you become a climate refugee. These are the things to be thought about now. There is no stopping or fixing this predicament. Prepare to adapt .

Move closer to work and walk there and get rid of the car. Use a bike, vacation at home, adopt rather than give birth, don't have pets or only 1 if you must, buy locally sourced foods and products, vote, vote green, boycott big corporations and stop importing stuff, don't go on cruises, teleconference rather than fly to meetings, buy second hand things, don't keep buying the newest smartphone every other week. Even all this is not enough.

Look I'll be honest here, the quality of life IS going to drop dramatically in the coming years, doesn't matter if we do it to ourselves by making radical lifestyle changes or not because nature is going to impose it upon us. So we might as well get ahead of it and start to adapt now. I have.

text: The vegan appropriation of the climate crisis is reckless. Climate change will require our focused attention, collective sacrifice and unprecedented political courage. Transformative, disruptive changes will be necessary to make fossil fuels reflect their costs to the environment, then transition society to 100% renewable energy. These will be painful enough without battling the perception that food activism may have hijacked the agenda.
author: Ivna C

text: Ivna C Veganism hasn‚Äôt by any means appropriated the climate change debate, witness the deafening silence of these two vegans. Veganism still seems to be the solution that dares not speak its name. Veganism must enter the debate: there is no other way in which ever richer projected populations can be fed while at the same time reducing land, water, chemical and fuel inputs
author: Mc el

text: ¬†@Mc el¬† There is no sustainable way to feed the population with just vegetables. They are not nutritionally dense enough. Mono cultures are extremely damaging, they take vast amount of space and destroy the ecosystem of the entire area. A lot of corporations and drug companies are interested in pushing the vegan message as they want to produce super processed foods that are making people sick.  Animal Farming can be done responsibly and can be more ecological than agriculture. Cattle is produced roaming free in many parts of the world, it requires sun, water and the shadow of trees and feeds on grasslands and mixed crop-livestock. This model should be praised. I get that people don't want to eat meat as a principal, but such agenda should not be forced on the rest of us. You need to keep fossil fuels underground. The video is spot on: it focuses on the things that will actually make a difference. Well done Greta for not letting your personal believes get in the way of an important message.
author: Ivna C

text: ¬†@The22726¬† A diet of soy is not nutritious enough for cattle (or for people for that matter). Grass where free pasture is possible, hay and mixed crop (with different grains) are organic ways animals can be fed. Some farmers use byproducts of other food production, such as orange juice and beer, as well as lupins, rapeseed meal and dried lucerne nuts. Promoting sustainable farming practices that make the most of the existing ecosystem is the way forward.

text: Current CO2 levels are 415 parts per million which equates to 0.0415% of the total atmosphere. Plant life ceases to function at about 160-180 parts per million. It has been reported that plant life is showing signs of benefiting from the increased CO2 by having increased growth, which could produce bigger crops.This could utilise more CO2. It may be the case that H2O in the atmosphere may be as important as CO2 for warming. CO2 levels have mostly decreased for the last 175 My, (Rothman, 2002). I suggest the subject is still in a state of flux possibly because the cycles are of such immense duration and variability. However, from a purely environmental/ecological perspective habitats MUST NOT be degraded, trees must be reinstated, farming must adopt modern methods such as no till, perpetual ground cover, 'mob' grazing and an end to factory farming and the like. This will help to increase SOM, SOC and eg Mycorrhizal fungi and will greatly reduce loss of soil, for example.

¬†@robin hood¬† Reality check. The dominant green house gas is Water Vapor which if one includes the clouds is responsible for 90 Percent of the green house effect. Carbon dioxide is a trace gas in the atmosphere 96 percent of which is there due to natural causes
the remaining 4 percent is due to mans activity. Reducing Carbon Dioxide emissions may make the average scientifically illiterate green supporter feel better about themselves but as for preventing small rises in the mean global temperature totally inifectual and pointless. One might as well stop breathing.  Irrespective of what some scientists say the planet stopped warming in 1998 and the growing season has shortend by two weeks since then. Remember Carbon Dioxide plus hydrogen is used by plants to manufacture sugars and starch. The hydrogren is split from water by photosynthesis. The increased Carbon Dioxide levels have enabled plants to further green the planet. Increased Carbon dioxide levels have enabled plants to reduce the number of pores on the underside of their leaves. These pores leak water vapor. So fewer pores mean the plants can make better use of the available water hence the greening of the planet

text: ¬†@xxwookey¬† It's much more than that. It's a whole ecosystem that needs to be rebuilt, an ecosystem that exists in forests not among saplings. It's something that builds up over the years, slowly. Species (of fungi, insects,...) that are adapted to mature environments, which means they are slow in reestablishing themselves. In at least some kinds of forests (I believe most) there is a gradual build up of organic material, which gets released as CO2, methane and such when clearcut. This is definitely true for the taiga, the northern forests.

text: Nuclear power is a Faustian pact. Its proponents are content to leave a toxic legacy of long-lasting waste from nuclear power stations to future generations for the sake of a temporary energy boost . . .
author: James Neilson Graham

text:
¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† Everything has waste. Nuclear power produces the least amount of waste than any energy system and it can be used as fuel in fourth generation reactors. 

If all the power you got in your lifetime came from nuclear power the waste you produced would fit inside a soda can. 70+ years of waste in a soda can. 

Windmills last for 15 years and then are scrapped. Each windmill uses 150-200L of machine oil. How much oil do you use and how much metal do you use with windmills in 70+ years? Enough to fit inside a soda can? No?
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† How many people have died from nuclear waste? How many people die from coal waste every year?
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@John Garrison¬†, You may be right about the present. My concern is with the future . . .
author: James Neilson Graham

text:
¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† And the future is Gen IV reactors that use the previous nuclear waste as fuel or Thorium or Fusion. 

The future is better for nuclear and the spent fuel than the present.
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@John Garrison¬†,  Thanks for your interesting comments. If the nuclear waste that is currently stored above ground is benign, why are governments around the world trying to find ways to dispose of it deep underground? Given the purported half-life of some of this stuff,  I think we're talking about thousands of years. That's what I mean by a legacy for future generations . . . .
author: James Neilson Graham

text:
¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† It's fine above ground, but there's such a irrational fear around nuclear waste that goverments are conceding to the demands of the people.  

When we get gen IV reactors up and running that's where the waste (or spent fuel) will go. Some pro nuke environmentalists want to call the areas where we store spent fuel "fuel banks".
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† And no it's not completely benign. Just the dangers are over-exaggerated. I mean where do we store coal waste? Coal emits 100x more radiation into the environment than nuclear (seriously Google that).
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@John Garrison¬†, I am curious to know what you would classify as coal waste and where it is stored. But the nuclear/coal waste equation is not, I would respectively suggest, comparing like with like. Nuclear waste is sealed. The true comparison, it seems to me, would be to uncork all the nuclear waste containers and then compare the radiation with coal . . .
author: James Neilson Graham

text:
¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† The point is you can't contain all the coal waste. It's not a solution coal has. 

The smoke while burning coal is coal waste and its stored in our lungs. The steam coming out of reactors is just steam.
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@John Garrison¬†,  Coal burning is undesirable - on that we agree. Germany is phasing out both coal and nuclear which seems pretty cool to me . . .
author: James Neilson Graham

text: ¬†@James Neilson Graham¬† Germany is building a pipeline from Russia to import natural gas and chopping down old growth forests to mine lignite coal.
author: John Garrison

text: ¬†@John Garrison¬†,  Looks like we're going to have to agree to differ . . .
author: James Neilson Graham
